top_comment.text:
I have always loved that, in the Silmarillion, the origin of evil was 
pride, and its first fruit was the destruction of harmony.  This resonates 
very strongly with many people's sense of morality, I think.  As Gandalf 
put it, in the beginning, not even the Dark Lord was evil.  Of course, he 
meant Sauron when he said this, but I think this holds true for Melkor as 
well.  The parallels between Melkor and Lucifer are obvious, but I strongly 
deny allegations that Tolkien intended a Christian allegory by this.  It's 
simply a storytelling necessity when you have a benevolent god and you wind 
up with a world full of suffering - at some point you've gotta write a 
rebellious angel or demigod into the story.﻿

comments.text:
+Urtane November I highly doubt your analysis. For example lembas is very 
clearly a reference to eucharist (lembas means "way bread", and I am sure 
that Tolkien as a linguist and traditional Catholic was very well aware of 
the term "viaticum" used of the eucharist). There are also references into 
the Ascension of Our Lord and to Assumption of Our Lady in the essay 
Athrabeth Finrod ah Andreth.

There is no strong allegory, but there is strong applicability, and for 
Tolkien that applicability worked within the framework of his own beliefs. 
(Besides, "Catholic" means "universal", or "whole/compatible with the 
whole"). For Tolkien, the word Catholic meant his own Catholic faith. Thus 
it is the most simple and probable conclusion that it meant "Roman" 
Catholic faith also in this context.
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
Tolkien wrote a long piece refuting any idea of Lord of the Rings as 
allegory. It is certainly a religious piece, but I think he is referring to 
the religion that exists within the text. The term Catholic does not refer 
to the Roman Catholic Church, it predates that. "Catholic" simply means "a 
coming together" or "a joining." I'm sorry, but I have to say it again, 
Tolkien openly said it was not allegory, and that he detests allegory. He 
stated that there may be some correlations that arise to a reader, but that 
those correlations are specific to that reader's experience.
comments.author: Urtane November

comments.text:
+dings da ? You do not seem to understand. Evil as absence of good does not 
mean that we should consider torture and similar evils as "nothing". Evil 
as absence of good deal with ontology, it is not meant to be some "measure" 
with which one could estimate the "evilness" of this or that moral evil.

If someone is ready to torture another human for example, he/she lacks 
compassion or at least his/hers faculty of setting him/herself into the 
position of another person. As a consequence (in the given example) we have 
a situation in which there is a lack or absence of comfort.

So did you get it? This deals with ontology, substance etc... the fact that 
a cruel person or cruel situation is lacking something does not mean that 
we should say to those suffering of those condition "oh... its just 
nothing".
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
+sakor88 
I cant help but strongly object to your understanding of evil as the 
abscence of good. On such a scale, 'nothing' would be among the things that 
are the least good. However, there are things that are infinitely worse 
than 'nothing', torture for example. We have to go into negative values to 
account for these things.

Also, what is it that you mean by good and why would we prefer that 
standard over any other one?

comments.text:
When the Valar wanted to send their messengers to Middle Earth they 
initially picked Curumo (Saruman) and Alatar (Blue #1). Yavanna  forced 
Aiwendil (Radagast the Brown) to join them. Alatar took his friend Pallando 
(Blue #2) with him. Olorin (Gandalf) arrives last and initially refuses 
Manwe's command, saying he is too frightened of Sauron. Manwe's wife Varda 
assures Gandalf that he is neither the weakest or the last of the Wizards, 
something that made Saruman take notice.

The colors are not really indicative of rank, although the Wizards all 
agreed that Saruman was their leader. Gandalf dies fighting the Balrog, but 
the Valar sent him back in a healed body with the authority the fallen 
Saruman held, effectively replacing him as the White.

comments.text:
+motherlode628 Tolkien had several different versions of the origin of 
orcs, including a version where Morgoth captured Elves and somehow 
corrupted them to orcs. However, he did abandon that theory. There are 
several versions of the tales of Silmarillion also, and Christopher Tolkien 
compiled and edited the most consistent combination of those tales into 
published Silmarillion. It was not necessary to include the origin of orcs 
into it but Christopher thought it to be important to at least somehow 
address it. Therefore he took the version that contradicted the least the 
other parts of the Silmarillion he had decided to choose.

However, even still the way the published Silmarillion alludes to the 
origin of orcs is indirect, and says that the wise of Eressea think it to 
be true that orcs were originally elves.

But like I said, there is no finished and "real" version of the 
Silmarillion in existence, since Tolkien wrote many parts of it again and 
again. Tolkien actually decided later, that the Silmarillion is a 
collection of legends compiled during the Third Age by Men, not by Elves.

comments.text:
In some of his letters, Tolkien said that Bombadil represents something or 
someone who is interested about things "in themselves", not how they are 
related to him. Therefore he is not tempted by the Ring, since he does not 
simply care.

We know that he is not God (Eru). We can be fairly certain that he is not 
Ainu (Vala or Maia = an angel, although it is possible that he is a Maia). 
It is suggested that he was in the World before Ainur arrived, and that 
would make him "the Eldest" since although Ainur existed "before" the 
world, they were outside of time and and arrived to the World AFTER it was 
created.

But... we can only make educated guesses and rule out certain things, such 
as he is not God, he is not Manwe or any other of the Valar. I myself enjoy 
the fact that we do not know everything about Tolkien's world. To explain 
everything would take away the spell. Everything does not just fall into 
neat and handy categories for our convenience.
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
What I've done is reading The Silmarillion, The Hobbit, The Lord of the 
Rings, watch The Hobbit (all three), watch The Lord of the Rings, read The 
Children of Húrin. Of course, I watched the LotR movies first, but it was 
long before I really got into the world.

I strongly believe reading The Silmarillion first gives meaning to the 
other works. There are so many references to the older days in both the 
Hobbit but especially LotR, that you won't understand otherwise. You'll 
just wonder who the hell they're talking about. Also, The Silmarillion is 
not very long. It's basically a long summary of everything that's happened, 
without going into detail in anything. It's kind of like an index.

After The Silmarillion, I think you should read the big works 
chronologically, meaning start with The Hobbit then LotR. Watching them 
afterwards is also a good idea, especially The Hobbit as there are many 
differences between the book and the films. When watching LotR, do make 
sure to get the extended editions. Otherwise you will swear at the TV at 
all the things that are cut out from the book. Even in the extended 
edition, there are many things missing, such as the beginning with Tom 
Bombadil.

After you've done this, you should then dig deeper into the Unfinished 
Tales and Children of Húrin. I've not read the former yet, but I'm halfway 
through the latter. The Children of Húrin is basically a chapter from 
Silmarillion told in depth in the same way The Hobbit and LotR are told. 
Also, The Children of Húrin is the first of the books I've read in English, 
whereas I've read the other in my native tongue, Danish. It's so much 
better in English. The way Tolkien writes reminds me of a modern 
Shakespeare.

Also, The Silmarillion is the best of them, since it gives so much more 
information that any of the other. It also makes you wonder more about the 
plot in The Hobbit and especially LotR. For instance, why did the Valar 
send the Istari to help against Sauron and not Tulkas? He loves war and 
battles, but they don't want him to beat up Sauron singlehandedly? It 
doesn't make sense to me, but I guess having a superhuman character run up 
to Murder, give Sauron his ring and defeat him 1v1 in hand-to-hand combat 
wouldn't make for an epic story.
comments.author: Dirty Poul

become again a bond by which you are constrained. Hope rather that in the 
end even the least of your desires shall have fruit. The love of Arda was 
set in your hearts by Iluvatar, and he does not plant to no purpose.

from heaven; which things the angels desire to look into.”

Melkor was originally the 13th member of the Valar, with powers over the 
extreme heats and colds of the world (which explains Mordor, Angaband and

and decided to fight all of the other Valar for dominion of the world.

bear hug and captured him. While on probation he manages to steal the 3

subsequently the Two Trees of Valinor (forcing the creation of sun and moon

revive the Trees) curses Melkor and called him Morgoth , the Dark Enemy.

comments.text:

Mythology often was propaganda, or at least used as such. It's an important 
part of a culture, and should be studied along with history.
The mythology of fictional cultures, however, is more or less just 
interesting. I'm a huge sucker for Elder Scrolls lore, but I won't pretend 
it'll help me beyond making it slightly easier for me to learn the 
mythologies of real life religions because of the ways they influenced 
Kirkbride and friends while writing the various myths present in the 
different races of men and mer.
As with any written work, you can end up learning about the time it was 
written in, or simply about the author as a person, but that's so general 
that I'll have to admit it's hard to count it as a reason why people should 
read fictional mythology.

Eru gave Men something Elves envy greatly- the ability to leave the world 
altogether when they die, to leave sadness and grief forever and presumably 
to join in the singing of the song of Arda. Elves are burdened by eternal 
sadness, memories that will never return and lands that will never be the 
same. When Aragorn dies he literally gives the gift back and surrenders the

she will leave the circles of the world where he cannot follow.

comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
+omnisc253

Yeah, Valinor was a pretty solid place, but it's only one portion of the 
world- and a removed portion of the world by the third age at that. I think 
the continued existence of men just gradually changed some fundamental 
aspect of Arda that sparked the eventual retreat of the Elves and the 
Valar's continued removal of themselves from worldly affaris.

It was in my mind that the Valar themselves favored the Elves because they 
were similar to the Valar- especially in the realm of death. The idea being 
that even the Valar didn't know what men's death truly meant. Also, 
considering what happened in the very first war, I would think the Valar 
would be more careful, especially after Elves and men started spreading to 
not completely mar the world again. Think about how much it took for them 
to embark on the war of wrath, after all. I also think the Valar knew 
somewhat of the potential for men to turn wicked. Certainly Elves could 
also do this, but I get the impression that it was more probable for men to 
turn their hearts, as their lives are shorter and they're in a way 
inherently less wise as a result.
As for men being unable to enter Valinor, that was because Valinor itself 
granted immortality to all that was there, right? It wasn't called the 
undying land for no reason. If Eru himself wanted men to have this gift 
called death then obviously they couldn't be permitted to enter(at least en 
masse, and not anyone), and Manwe understood this.

I'm not so sure- when Ainur enter in the picture it's hard to say. 
Obviously when Eru created Arda, at least I think, he created for the 
children, even though he permitted Ainur to descend into it. Eventually the 
Valar at least realized this, and I think that's the main reason why they 
stopped interfering so much- why they allowed Morgoth to do as much as he 
did. They wanted the rightful heirs of Arda to overcome the issues 
themselves(which obviously they couldn't do). The Valar did of course 
intervene. I think if men had been unable to anything to Sauron, regardless 
of if he made the ring, help eventually would have been sent. Once the 
influence of the Ainur is truly gone, then men are left to their fate, and 
instead of the Ainur messing around within the song, they can watch it 
unfold without direct action. I also think that Frodo destroyed the ring, 
even though Gandalf assisted him plays an extremely important role in all 
of this. It ultimately wasn't an Istari who defeated Sauron in combat or 
destroyed the ring- it was one of the children. After this I think it was 
especially evident to the Valar that the children's time is now- though 
they did assist, it was a child who completed the deed. It'd be like if 
some hero of men delivered the final crippling blow against Morgoth in the 
war of wrath. Even though the Valar cleared the way and smote Thangorodrim, 
it still would have been a man who defeated Morgoth- and that would've 
meant a ton.
comments.author: PandAgroupinc

comments.text:
+PandAgroupinc The whole 'mystery after death' thing is simply a result of 
the author himself being human and possibly trying to make death seem more 
optimistic than it actually is. Middle earth is just one continent of Arda, 
between it and Aman the Elves again get the better deal. Valinor is 
essentially a paradise where nothing dies.

The Valar immediately went to war against Melkor at his full strength when 
they found out that the Elves had awoken and would be at his mercy. Then 
again in the War of Wrath even after all Feanor and the Noldor had done. By 
contrast they did nothing when Men awoke. Even the Men of Numenor, after 
all they had done to fight Morgoth and never once committing a crime 
against the Valar, were forbidden to even visit Valinor, during a long era 
of peace no less. 

Had Sauron not brought about his own defeat by creating the One Ring (and 
making himself far more vulnerable by diluting his power) would Men have 
just been left to their fate?
comments.author: omnisc253

comments.text:
It depends on how you look at it, though I definitely would say men are the 
favorite- but in a strange way. Sure elves have immortality, but that's 
only as far as arda is concerned. The elves are completely tied to arda and 
it's fate. Men are however free from this. Elves go to the halls of Mandos 
when slain, but as for where men go nobody save Eru knows. It's also 
heavily implied that Eru called death the special gift to men(if he didn't 
say it outright, which I think he did), which is to say their fate is 
beyond the world's. Elves die with the world, whereas men would somehow 
trudge onward.

Also, if the elves truly were favored, then they wouldn't have gradually 
left Middle-earth. The world is given over to men to control, but the elves 
just leave.
Elves only seem to be favored if you consider death to be outright bad- 
which isn't the point in this case because of the unknowns associated with 
it, which imo is one of the more interesting aspects of Tolkien's 
legendarium.
comments.author: PandAgroupinc

comments.text:
+DuBaas007
Most Tom Bombadil theories have one or more of the following problems:
1. They make Tom too strong (he would fall to Sauron with the Ring, so he's 
got a clear limit, and he's definitely not Eru).
2. They make him too weak (he's not mortal, nor does the Ring affect him 
like it does the Maia)
3. They don't account for Goldberry, when any decent explanation would 
explain both of them.

I've also heard that he's the Witch King, which is interesting, but not 
something I buy into at all. And I've read a somewhat tongue-in-cheek 
argument that he's actually some eldritch dark lord waiting for the others 
to take out Sauron for him so he can move in. And I've heard that it's Aulë 
and Yavanna, that he's some unnamed Maia, that it's Manwë, Eru, or just 
some unknown nature spirit (usually parallels to Ungoliant- whom is also 
one of the legendarium's big mysteries- are brought up in these cases).

My favorite theory is that he's the embodiment of the Flame Imperishable, 
like a Holy Spirit-esque being. It meshes well with the Catholic influence 
we already know about. It doesn't explain Goldberry, though, and that's a 
problem... some kind of nymph? A Maia? *shrug*

I find it extremely unlikely that he's weaker than or equal to a Maia in 
strength, considering his relationship with the Ring.

I once heard that Tolkien implied that he did have an actual idea of what 
Tom was, but simply chose not to reveal it. So in theory there is a 
"potentially canon" explanation for him that we'll just never know about. I 
find that both very cool and very frustrating at the same time.

Along with the Entwives and Ungoliant, it's just one of those things we're 
going to have to accept not ever knowing about.
comments.author: Mr. ZAP

comments.text:
Tom Bombadil is a mystery indeed.  Known to the Elves as Iarwain Ben-Adar, 
to the Dwarves as Forn, to Men as Orald, he displays many of the 
characteristics of the Ainur, and many theorize he is one of the lesser 
Ainur, ie., the Maia (of which kind are also Gandalf, Saruman, and 
Sauron).  But since other Maia are vulnerable to the seduction of the Ring 
(witness Saruman's fall) and Bombadil clearly is not (witness his casual 
disinterest in FotR), it seems unlikely he is a Maia.  Is he a Vala then?  
Well, Tolkien clearly enumerates the Valar and seems to imply that there 
are none unaccounted for.  Is he Eru?  Tolkien went on the record and 
explicitly rejected that.

So, we can fairly confidently say Bombadil is not Eru, not Vala, not Maia, 
and not mortal.  So what the heck is he??!

The best guess is probably that Bombadil is some sort of Earth- or 
nature-spirit who was created along with the plants and animals, during the 
Music of the Ainur and before the First Day.  He is likely a result of the 
original, uncorrupted music (ie., before Melkor's revolt).  He is not of 
the Ainur but neither is he mortal; this combination of traits would 
explain both his immunity to the Ring as well as his relative indifference 
to the struggles between the Free People and the Dark Lord.
comments.author: nfinn42

top_comment.text:
Love the video, but one little inaccuracy threw me off a wee bit. Dwarves 
were not created in cooperation with Iluvatar. Aule became impatient while 
waiting for the coming of the "Children of Iluvatar" (men and elves) and so 
secretly created a race of his own: the dwarves. He could not, however, 
find out how to give them free will, and as a result they were bound to the 
will of Aule. Of course, Aule couldn't keep them a secret from Iluvatar 
(basically God), who became enraged by this and almost destroyed Aule's 
creations. But as he was about to smite them he was moved by their pleas 
for pity, spared them, and bestowed the gift of independence on them. They 
became known as the "adopted children" of Iluvatar, but were put to sleep 
deep beneath the mountains until the coming of the elves in Arda.﻿

comments.text:
It is because people have poor recollections of specifics of stories. 
Unless you studied its nuance in literature class, or read it very 
recently, you are going to have a different recollection of it.

I happen to have a pretty deep understanding of that particular passage, 
having studied it in college and remember it pretty well.

Eru wasn't even enraged at Melkor for all the discord he sowed within the 
Song. He did Eru-splain the facts to him at the end, but it was without 
anger or rage.

He was also not enraged at Aule over the Dwarves. It was an extremely 
powerful and emotional passage which displayed what true mercy, love, and 
desire to do and be good are all about.

comments.text:
+ScorchedPainter
 what happenned was that Aule desired Children of his own to teach and to 
instruct and tried to make creatures using stone and his arts (hence the 
Elves call Dwarves 'Gonnhorim' , masters of stone), but he couldn't make 
them do anything independently. He did it so secretly even his wife Yavanna 
did not know.

Eru asked Aule why he did what he did and why he wasn't content with the 
coming of Elves and Men, and in shame Aule raised his hammer to destroy the 
Dwarven fathers (and mothers) but to his surprise they recoiled and begged 
him not to destroy them. Eru had indeed granted Dwarves sentience and a 
place as his 'adopted' Children- but warned Aule that strife will come 
between the natural and the adopted. Eru also made Aule lay the Fathers and 
mothers (apart from Durin, who lay alone) in tombs of stone under the 
mountains until the Elves awoke but before Men awoke.

Oddly enough this also led to the creation of the Eagles and Ents- Yavanna 
found out what Aule was up to and complained that he should have told her, 
since now in addition to the Elves and Men the Dwarves will likely damage 
her forests with no pity as they do not know Yavanna's work. She complained 
to the boss of the Valar, Manwe (sort of their big bro) and he listened for 
the will of Eru (which was communicated directly to his mind) and came to a 
decision; he would be granted the use of Eagles to patrol the mountains and 
forests  while among the trees the Ents would walk.

comments.text:
Tolkien was a Catholic and made it pretty darn clear, though 
unintentionally, that his mythos for Middle-Earth was basically a 
retelling/allegory for Christianity and specifically Catholicism.

You don't get the concepts of Wizards/Balrogs = Angels/Demons,
A single God who creates many seraph (highest order angels/demigods),
A Demigod who rebels against his Creator and Falls (a la LDS cosmology and 
John Milton's Paradise Lost) taking a portion of the angels with him,
A Virgin Mary like image in the Elven Queen Galadrial,
A sacrifice of a pure, good-hearted Son of Man (Frodo) to atone for the 
sins of the world (represented by the Ring of Power [which is a symbol of 
the evil which tyrannical kings of men in the real world have done], rings 
are symbolic of kings, and a common epitaph for kings is "ring-giver") by 
descending into a literal Hell on Earth to destroy it.
Without thinking, this is all very Christian.

comments.text:
You are perhaps missing a bit of back-story. C.S. Lewis had been a WW1 
fighter pilot, and went on in the '20s & '30s to write some quite 
successful and popular work for children and adolescents. (The Narnia 
stories.) He bumped into a chap by the name of Tolkien, who was by day a 
professor of Linguistics at Oxford, and by night a fellow fantasy writer, 
who'd written the Hobbit. They had a discussion, over a few beers, that 
went something like this - Fantasy is a genre for children. No, fantasy is 
a genre in which nobody has yet written serious adult literature. But you 
can't write adult literature in fantasy, because it becomes something else. 
Only if you let it. I bet you I can write a sequel to the Hobbit, which is 
not directed at children, and which will receive some acceptance as adult 
literature. The bet was made in about 1935. C.S. Lewis paid up in about 
1952.

I have been working on reading "Simarillion" since somewhere around 1964 or 
so. That is when I first learned of J. R. R. Tolkien while on a church bus

becoming a popular author but the mythology was not lost on some of us who 
studied such things. The million pages of notes is probably just about 
right, some of which was published in various places over the next decade 
of so until his son put together something that could be published as a 
whole in 1977, which I have never read.

Maybe it is time to pick up reading it again. I have no idea where all my 
notes and saved articles are, so maybe the book will have to do. The good 
side is there are plenty of Tolkien historians and 'cliff notes' available  
now to help sort things out, which didn't exist during my first try at 
understanding the universe according to J. R. R. Tolkien.

Thanks for sharing this and giving my mind something to work on, something 
it used to find very enjoyable.

+rendilkraesin J.R.R cannot publish anything anymore. He did have other 
theories that are published also posthumously in the History of 
Middle-earth series. I recommend you read Morgoth's Ring. Tolkien abandoned 
orcs-from-elves theory. Just because he did not "officially canonize" any 
other theory does not mean that one should return to abandoned theories.

Christopher Tolkien seems to think that his father's last theory was that 
orcs were originally Men. Tolkien also wanted to revise the chronology of 
the Elder Days to fit with his new ideas but he did not have time to do it.

The problematic of the elvish origin is not that it is sad thing that elves 
were corrupted. The problem is metaphysical... how could Morgoth change the 
fate of Eru's Children so that immortal Elves become mortal orcs.

Of course one can have a personal head canon any way he likes it to be. I 
myself think that Glorfindel of Rivendel is the same person as Glorfindel 
of Gondolin. It is true that it is only one note where he says so, but he 
did not seem to change that view anywhere.

comments.text:
+sakor88 I'm painfully aware that JRR Tolkien liked to revisit, revise, and 
borrow over his characters and histories, which leaves the reader to 
consider many options.  In such matters, there is no "right theory" because 
it is not a case of mathematics or physics, it's literary interpretation. 
 I will alter my interpretation when JRR Tolkien publishes the 
authoritative revision, or when I find another of the latent possibilities 
more useful.  If you know of one, I'd be happy to hear about it.

I understand why Tolkien became uncomfortable with the elf-orc origin 
issue, and if he were here today I would happily offer some inputs for him. 
 One of the possibilities I might suggest is that he was correct in the 
first place and just needed to accept that it was possible.  I don't like 
it either, because it is a sadness on the world which should not be taken 
lightly.

On another issue with options, I have always interpreted the Glorfindel who 
appears in the LotR to be the same one who was reported to have died 
defending Gondolin in the Silmarillion.  I don't need anyone's permission 
or endorsement for that choice, either.  It is strictly what works for me 
artistically.
comments.author: rendilkraesin

comments.text:
+rendilkraesin It does not matter even if 99% of the fans would consider 
the theory to be right one. Tolkien abandoned the theory. Christopher 
Tolkien himself says that the published Silmarillion is just one possible 
combination of the tales, and not necessarily "correct" one. J.R.R. himself 
later considered the tales of Silmarillion to be legends from the Third Age 
and that there were several versions of them around.

comments.text:
Actually, in the Silmarillion, Tolkien talks about how when the Valor first 
discovered that the elves had come to life and tried to meet them, the 
elves were terrified (they were confronted by a giant Valor who rode a 
giant horse, and they had never seen anything like it before). Some elves 
panicked and ran off into the dark and were lost forever. These elves were 
captured by Melkor and were tortured, twisted, and corrupted to his 
purposes. This is one of the reasons that the elves hate the orcs so much 
and why elven crafted metal glows with hatred whenever orcs are near... 
they were the weakest at heart, and are the corrupted versions of 
themselves. They even briefly mention this in the movies, when Sauruman is 
talking to his urukai.
comments.author: Amy Nelson

comments.text:
In the Silmarillion it says pretty specifically that Melkor sidetracked 
some of the elves on the first journey towards Valinor, that he "tortured & 
twisted" them to make them into orcs eventually.  In the process, they 
became spiritually and physically inferior to the elves, but they could 
reproduce quickly.  Later eugenics programs by Saruman & Sauron (e.g. the 
Uruk-Hai orc-men, and Olag-Hai orc-trolls(?)) remedied the physical gap 
somewhat, but not enough to matter in the end.

top_comment.text:
Discounting Tolkien's writing because it was a bit racist is like 
discounting Aristotle's science/philosophy because he thought the Earth was 
the center of the universe. Tolkien, like Aristotle (and like all of us) 
was a product of his time. He grew up in the same time period that tried to 
use evolution to prove that white people were superior to all other races.
I'm not saying that we should glorify any inherent racism of the stories! 
But I am saying we can read the tale for what it is as a singularly 
masterful work of fantasy literature while being aware of the context from 
which the author was writing and where society has moved since then.

also, as a point of interest, I find it overlooked in all these vitriolic 
comments that two of the main characters in LOTR are made all the more 
special by the fact that they overcome centuries of racial divide to become 
companions for life. Pretty progressive if you ask me!﻿

My biggest question regarding the lore of middle earth (excuse me if this 
has been answered elsewhere) - did Tolkien say anything definitive 
regarding the mortality of Ainur? As far as I can remember (and this may be 
me confusing book and film) in LOTR we see Saruman, the Balrog of Moria and 
(arguably) Gandalf the Grey all die. Add to this the balrogs killed 
fighting for Melkor, and I assume some kind of death is possible. Is this 
just a loss of a physical form - ie did Gandalf the Grey die and then his 
spirit be granted a new form, or was he preserved from death (which would

comments.text:
All the Ainur are spirits. However, many of those Ainur that descended into 
Arda wanted to have dealings with the Children of Ilúvatar (Elves, Men and 
also Dwarves), and therefore it was easier if they had a body of sorts. In 
many cases it was some kind of "vestment" that reflected their personality, 
but some took actual physical bodies. However, such a process used some of 
the inherent power of Ainu-spirit in question. Morgoth took it to extremes 
and tried to control the entire matter of world and therefore he was 
actually inherently weaker in the end of the First Age than Sauron was, but 
had enormous control and domination over the physical world.

In a sense, when Ainu took a physical body, he became in a sense "an 
incarnate" like Elves and Men (that is, body-soul-composite, person that 
has both body and spirit instead of just spirit). That made them vulnerable 
and "mortal", since death is separation of soul from body and body is not 
invulnerable.

When the Istari are sent to Middle-earth, they must take physical bodies 
for themselves in order to relate better to peoples of Middle-earth with 
their weaknesses, problems and pains. That made them also "mortal".

Sauron also took physical body, and lost it at least three times. Every 
time he lost some of his original power. First time he lost his body in the 
destruction of Númenor, and he lost his ability to assume fair form. He 
took new body relatively quickly, but was "killed" again by Gil-galad and 
Elendil. It took much longer for him to assume new body, but he was able to 
do so, because the Ring into which he had poured much of his original power 
still existed. When the Ring was destroyed he lost his power to maintain 
his physical body and was killed again. He was not able to assume another 
body again and became a spirit that could not affect the physical world 
anymore.
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
There were two Blue Wizards. They were called Alatar and Pallando. Tolkien 
had only few theories about their deeds. First he seemed to think that they 
had failed in somewhat similar manner as Saruman and had established some 
dark cults. Later he thought that they had succeeded in helping the people 
in the East (and possibly also in South) to rebel against Sauron, and thus 
the armies that attacked against Gondor, Rohan and Northrons were not SO 
overwhelmingly huge because all of East (and possibly South) were not under 
Sauron's full dominion.

comments.text:
Tolkien is using lots of concepts of religions that actually exist through 
his Syncretism he's blending many concepts to come out with his own fantasy 
world view of creation.  Panentheism is his prime initial use describing 
the void outside of Eru initial creator of reality that we can enjoy as his 
creation and his creations' creations to come.  The great spider Ungoliant 
came from the void, it did not come from the "divinity" of Eru Illivater. 
 The void is present distinctly from Eru the divine being who is filling it 
with creation of his.  
Panentheism is better to describe Tolkien's fantasy certainly not 
monotheistic where creation comes from only one divine being who needs no 
assistance from any other, as this type of divinity is paradoxically 
everywhere all the time and knows everything and is without mistakes and 
also controls the void as well as everything else, which Eru doesn't.  
Henotheism describes better the way in which all the Valar, demi-gods and 
minor angle like demi gods come into the world.  The creations of the earth 
called Arda are made by his demi gods, not by Eru. Eru seems to delight in 
seeing what others would do or add to his creations making his creations by 
themselves not perfect or desirable on their own.  He reserves spots for 
his workings and lets them do essentially anything else.  And since the 
creatures and sentient creatures may worship the Valar as gods, Henotheism 
fits this description.  Valar are worshiped as gods and create as gods with 
very little guidance from Eru.  Roman pantheon mythology followed similar 
lines as Tolkien:  Initially Gaea and Chaos are from nowhere one divine the 
other the void have union to make creation. Gaea and Chaos and in one myth 
Eros god of love are primordial gods.  They gave birth to Uranus 
originally, then Uranus and Gaea give birth to the Titans which created 
more to the world. Then Uranus gets overthrown by a Titan Cronus, Gaea and 
and Cronus give birth to the Olympic gods which gave birth to more stuff 
and won dominion over the world from their prior creators the Titans. 
 Henotheism is strongly used, a little panentheism is being used as its 
okay to worship any of the Olympic gods including their defeated 
predossesors the Titans such as Saturn during Saturnalia; Saturn or Cronus 
being the father of Zeus and many of the Olympic gods.

captions.text:
The Lord of the Rings has lots of 
different kinds of people:

Elven people, dwarvin people, tree people,
half-sized people, even people people.

There's, like, a million pages  of
background explaining this world

that goes much deeper than the books
or the movies

but if you don't want to read 
it all,
here's a four-minute summary.
Starting with wizards.

It's easy to mistake the wizards
as humans trained in magic,
like elsewhere.

But, in The Lord of the Rings, wizards
are low-ish level angels.

They're called The Istari
(get ready for lots of names in this video)

and there are ﬁve of them:
Sauroman the white, Gandalf the gray,

Radgast the brown, and the two
Blue Wizards.

Their power comes mostly from being
supernatural and not so much from book
learning.

Their sent(by who? We'll get to that in a
second) to help the people of
world stand against evil.
Not wildly successfully, either.

Sauroman, the leader of the ﬁve,
with a mind of metal and wheels

gets corrupted, Radgast gets distracted
by all the pretty nature, the Blue Wizards

just kind of fade into the east,
possibly starting cults of magic,

and it's only Gandalf that stays
true to the quest.

Now, where there's angels, there's a
god, and in this universe,
that's Eru Ilúvatar.

In the beginning, there was not but Eru,
and the infinite timeless nothing,

which is rather boring, so he created
lots of angels to keep him company.

Ilúvatar's angels are called The Ainur
and are divided into two groups:

The Valar, guardians of the world,
of which there are fourteen.

(or ﬁfteen, depending on who you
want to count)
And their servants, The Mayar.

So, the wizards are the Istari, a
subset of the Mayar, which serve the
Valar, all created by Ilúvatar.

Ilúvatar, and all his angels sang
together to make the world.

The harmony started out great, but
there was one Valar, named Melkor,

and just from the name, Melkor,
you know what's going to happen

even before learning he's also the
smartest, and the most powerful
of the angels.
And also a bit of a loner.

Melkor didn't want just to be part of
the chorus, like his dimmer Valar
co-workers,
he wanted his own song in creations.

And so, his voice became discordant
from the others...

and created all the suffering and evil
in the world.

But, Melkor's song also attracted some
Maylar to his side,

including the balrogs, which means the
balrog is a low-level angel,

making him on the same level
of the power org chart as Gandalf.

Which explains why an old man can
hold his ground against a giant lava
monster.

Through his discordant singing,
Melkor also created some of the evil

creatures in the world, such as the
dragons and trolls, which

ﬁnally gets us to things that aren't
angels.

Other valar also made their own
non-angelic creations, though in a more
cooperative spirit with Ilúvatar.

Manwë makes the Great Eagles,
Aulë made the dwarves,

and his wife, Yavanna made all of the
animals and the plants in the world,

before capping off that minor task with
The Ents, her own
race of sentient creatures.

While Ilúvatar seemed happy
to leave it to his Vala

to make *most* of the stuff,
he did personally create
men and elves,

which makes them special,
and kind of above all the other living
creatures.
Sorry, Dwarves.

And, of these two, the men
are Ilúvatar's favorite children.

And, he shows this by giving men
shorter lives than everybody else,
and also the gift of death?
Thanks a lot, Dad.

But, their short live set them apart
from the other creatures, and they

aren't tied to the music of creation
and the world, like everyone else.

And so, are able to forge their own
futures.

These qualities make them the
"Get Stuff Done" species of Middle Earth.

Elves, on the other hand, are so
connected to the world that practically

made of nature. Same with the dwarves
in their own way
and the Ents, of course.

These species all but follow the flow
of nature, and it's partly why the

humans have such a hard time getting
them to do anything.

Even when faced with armies of Orcs,
which brings us to Orcs.

Melkor was powerful, but couldn't make
his creatures as great as the elves and

men, and so cheated by corrupting some
of them in the beginning and

selectively breading them over the
generations into these creatures.

This business Melkor was up to of
torturing elves, making monsters,

recuiting angels from the other side
eventually, but unsurprisingly, led to

a war that Melkor looses and got him
banished into the void.

All of the conflict in
The Lord of The Rings comes long after the

epic Good vs. Evil fight of
that universe.

Sauron, the Big Bad, who caused all of
the trouble in these books,

was just one of the Mayar, though
an unusually powerful one

who started his career as Melkor's
lieutenant.

After the war, he did make a ring to
focus his strength, but that's a
story for another time.
Last, but not least, we have the Hobbits.

Even though they seem related to Dwarves,
what with the living underground and the

vertical challenge, Hobbits are a
subspecies of men.

For such an important and pivotal race,
there is little written of their origin,
other than the phrase "related to men".

Turns out, with a million pages,
you still can't talk about everything,
just like in a four-minute video.
♪ *Hello Internet #13 in background*  ♪

title: The Lord of the Rings Mythology Explained (Part 1)
